bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Commandante A. Herrera, June 25, 1921

div1.p: Hanson criticizes Peruvian officials for undermining yellow fever work.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Commandante A. Herrera, June 25, 1921
div1.opener:
Dear Dr. Carter:
Unfortunately the Prefecto
of Libertad was changed with results as
you will notice by the enclosed.
Hanson
DIRECCION
DE LA
CAMPAÑA SANITARIA
CONTRA LA FIEBRE AMARILLA
EL LOS DEPARTAMENTOS DEL NORTE
----
OFICINA CENTRAL
----
Chiclayo, Peru.
June 25,1921.
Comandante H. Herrera H,
Prefecto of Libertad,
Trujillo:
Sir:
div1.p:
Yesterday I received a telegram from Trujillo of which I enclose copy. This
telegram expresses a sentiment which is so contrary to all the personal manifes-
tations which you have repeatedly made to me that it seems incredible that you
could have been the author of such a message. It is quite evident that there is
a very serious misunderstanding of the importance of the work which is being
carried on by the Sanitary Campaign for the Eradication of Yellow Fever from
Peru. Many persons are talking profusely about a subject on which they have in-
sufficient knowledge, and in the execution of which they have no experience.

I am compelled to conclude that you have been very improperly advised in
the matter, because it had always been my opinion that you desired to do the
right thing for your people and your country, and once the matter were explained
in its true light you would take the right steps to bring this about regardless
of the pressure of private interests. This situation of the insidious advance of
the yellow fever towards the south constitutes a very serious menace to the en-
tire Republic of Peru, as well to the adjacent Countries. This should be care-
fully considered by those who are making the great outcry for the removal of the
restrictions on travel,- they should find out what these restrictions are, and by
whom made before they submit demands which can not be complied with. Neither the
Government nor the Management of the Sanitary Campaign have any desire to impose
useless restrictions either on passenger travel or Commerce. In regard to restric-
tions on maratime commerce none has been recommended by the Director of the Cam-
paign, as will be seen by the following extract of letter which I have written to
#2. Prefecto of Libertad, June 25, 1921.
Sanitary Authorities in Guayaquil, Ecuador. (See copy of extract enclosed)

In regard to passenger travel however the most rigid restrictions have been
requested from the very beginning of the Campaigns, and if these regulations had
been taken seriously by the authorities concerned there neither would have been
yellow fever in the Department of Lambayeque or that of Libertad this year, and
your people would not at the present time be smarting under the sting of refringe-
ment on their personal liberties. The unfortunate restrictions on commerce also
would have been avoided, which have resulted on account of overdue precautions
adopted by some of the neighboring countries. These neighboring countries have
learned from long and bitter experience what it means to have both endemic and
epidemic yellow fever, and very naturally do not intend to take any chances of
permitting it to re-enter after it once has been completely eliminated.

The attitude which you assume by virtue of your telegram to the President
and to the Minister of Fomento, has the effect of declaring that we
do not know what we are talking about, or that we are all dishonest and that we
are carying on the campaign for some ulterior motive. It will therefore be necessary
for you to produce your proofs to sustain either the one or the other or both,
and secure a complete reorganization of the campaign. It will also be necessary
for you to convince the neighboring countries that neither the present nor the
other epidemics of the last two years, in Peru, have been of yellow fever. If
you can do this, you will be entitled to send such messages as the one enclosed,
but under no other condition.

To what “aservación uniforme Cuerpo Médico reunido mi Despacho dia 8 del
presente” do you refer? There was no such uniform agrement at the metting which
I attended.

Why do you think that the five isolated cases to which you refer lessens
the menace to the rest of the country? Has it not occured to you that instead
of having one single concentrated focus this would indicate a lamentable pro-
pagation with an equally increased risk of propagationspread to new territory? Upon
#3. Prefecto of Libertad, June 25, 1921.
what grounds do you base your assertions in regard to the neglect of the work
in Paijan? What competent authority have you consulted in order to justify you
in making public statements of this kind in a matter which a question of
life and death both to individuals and to commerce?

Among the patients seen by me in the Department of Libertad, in the Pro-
vince of Trujillo, there have been the following findings:

These patients have gone
to bed with a sudden attack of headache, pain in the back in the kidney re-
gion, discomfort and pain in the stomach which has rapidly been followed by
nausae and vomiting, great prostration from the beginning which has con-
tinued through all the period of the illness. The eyes have been red and
injected, tongue heavily coated dorsally with red margins and tip, gums
injected some bleeding spontaneously others on slight pressure, this has
been most marked in the portion of the gum immediately incontact with the
teeth. The severest cases have had great discomfort all over the body
but most pronounced in kidney region and stomach. The temperature has
varied from 38 C to 41 C, and the pulse has been relatively low for the
temperature, with a fall in the pulse rate characteristic of yellow
fever. The urine has shown an abundance of albumen in the third and
fourth day of the disease, in some of the severe, fatal cases, albumen
has presented itself in the first and second day of the illness. Some
of these patients have had black vomit, samples of which were kept for
exhibition to any one who wished to assure himself in the matter. None
of the attacked gave any history of ever having had a similar disease
previously. In these cases as the disease progressed the conjuncti-
vae has gradually tured from the red injected appearance to a reddish
yellow and later to a yellow brassy color, throughout there has been a
partial edematous condition of the conjunctivae which is distinct from
the condition seen in the icterus due to chronic malaria or other hepatic
disturbances. After the fourth day the skin has commenced to show icterico
changes, in proportion to the severity of the disease and its duration.
In those who have recovered the albuminuria has disappeared.

The autopsies practiced on those dying have shown marked cutaneous
and subcutaneous yell discoloration, yellowness and fatty degeneration of
the liver, potechial hemmorhages in the pleura, yellow discoloration of
the serous surfaces, parenchymatous nephritis diffuse. Stomach with con-
gestion, hyperaemia and catarrhal swelling of the mucosa, and contents
black coffe color in nearly all cases.

The above has served as the basis for our diagnosis, togather with
our experience and observation of the cases in the Departments of Piura and
Lambayeque. We have found that these cases have a direct relationship with
the number of stegomya in the locality, and that the elimination of the stego-
mya is followed by a disappearance of the disease. Efforts to isolate cases has
proven of practically no value in that when the people know that they are to be
taken to place of isolation they hide the cases until the period of infectivity
#4. Prefecto of Libertad, June 25, 1921.
has passed. In the first epidemics of the Department of Piura we established
isolation hospitals, with the idea orf of immediately removing every suspi-
cious case of sickness from the general population, and in that manner lessen
the opportunities for propagation. In theory this seems to be a good measure
but in practice it has not given the results expected for the reason mentioned
above. This measures gives rise to much resistance on the part of the people,
and the political authorities have not seen fit to assure its enforcement.

The experience of the greatest authorities of modern times, in the matter
of the control and eradication of yellow fever, such as the late General Gorgas
with whom I personally discussed this problem in connection with the Piura
Campaign, and Dr. Henry R. Carter, Assistant Surgeon General of the United
States Public Health Service, and special advisor of the International Health
Board, (one of the greatest authorities in the world on yellow fever) have
abandoned both the practice of isolation of the sick, except by the use of
mosquito bars, and the general fumigation of houses. They recommend an in-
tensive campaign against the stegomya larva as the surest and most effective
sanitary measure. The campaign in the Departments of Lambayeque and Libertad
are conducted on this basis.

The recent publications in the Trujillo daily papers show a very evident
lack of knowledge of the epidemiology of yellow fever, as well as a total lack
of comprehension of what is, or what is not, effective practical sanitary work.

Trusting that you will give this matter the careful consideration which
it deserves for the best interests of the country, I am
div1.closer:
Very respectfully yours, Henry Hanson, M.D.,
Director of Sanitary Campaign
against Yellow Fever, in the
Departments of the North. Copy to,
Direccion de Salubridad,
Lima, Peru.
International Health Board,
New York, N.Y., U.S.A.
